Award.AwardTitle: The 4th International Workshop on Fluid Structure Interaction Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The 4th International Workshop on Fluid-Structure Interaction Problems (http://www2.ims.nus.edu.sg/Programs/016wfluid/index.php) will be hosted by the Institute for Mathematical Sciences (IMS) at National University of Singapore during 30 May - 3 June 2016. The workshop aims to bring together mathematicians, computational scientists, and engineers having a common interest in solving fluid-structure interaction problems. The ultimate goal is to initiate new research collaborations that improve on existing techniques and generate ideas for new approaches. Funding from the NSF is sought to support the travel of ten US participants, including graduate students, post-docs and junior faculty.

This workshop will address many challenging and important computational and modeling techniques for fluid-structure interaction problems in biological flows, multiphase flows, material sciences, and manufacturing processes. It will provide a platform to exchange, promote and generate ideas across a wide range of research areas in scientific computing and applications. The workshop will also introduce US researchers to a broad international community, expands and creates research collaborations with their international peers, and provides research and career counseling for junior US researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 4th International Workshop on Fluid-Structure Interaction Problems was hosted by the Institute for Mathematical Sciences (IMS) at National University of Singapore during 30 May - 3 June 2016. The workshop brought together mathematicians, computational scientists, and engineers having a common interest in solving fluid-structure interaction problems. The funding from the NSF covered the airfare for all and the hotels for some of the ten US participants, including three invited speakers, three graduate students, three post-docs and one junior faculty.

Many problems in applied sciences, such as biofluid mechanics, porous media, manufacturing processes and material sciences, require understanding of fluid-structure interactions, in which geometric objects such as interfaces or filaments move and interact with a surrounding fluid. Examples include behavior of soft tissues under morphogenesis and other internally generated shape change, which is important in understanding tumor growth, wound healing, and reinforcement of load-bearing blood vessels; the dynamics of inextensible vesicles in an incompressible viscous fluid, which is important in designing drug-carrying capsules; and the aerodynamics/hydrodynamics of natural flyers and swimmers, which is important in designing robotic vehicles with similar flight/swimming capabilities. In material sciences, the evolution of threshold-driven interfaces for nucleation, cluster growth, and droplet interaction sheds light on processes such as spiral formation in excitable media, the shape theory of crystals, dendritic aggregation, and phase separation by surface tension. The topics of the workshop include mathematical modeling, numerical methods, high performance computing and mathematical and numerical analysis for fluid-structure interaction problems and applications. This workshop provided a forum for applied mathematicians, computational scientists, and engineers worldwide to present new and emerging research developments and future directions in computational mathematics and applications, to exchange research results and ideas, and to promote international and local
research and educational cooperation and connections.


The funding from the NSF brought a group of young US researchers in mathematics including graduate students to participate the workshop. They presented their work to an international community, interacted with their international peers, learned new research development and formed collaborations. The workshop brought the visibility of the research by US speakers to a broad international audience.
